--Echo 10-2019: LVEF 26%, LVDD 5.96, G3DD, mild MR
--Echo 4-2019: LVEF 10%, LVDD 6.18, no thrombus, mild MR/TR
--Echo 11-2018 @ UofL: LVEF 13%
--Echo 10-2018: LVEF 25%, LVDD 6.6, mild MR/PR
--Echo 3-2017: LVEF 39%, LVDD 5.8, mild MR
--Echo 8-2015: LVEF 30-35%, LVDD 6.00, mild MR

--s/p MI and PCI to RCA around 2014

COPD
OSA
CKD, stage III
Persistent Afib
Obesity, class II
Pulm HTN
Depression
Was admitted on 2021-08-08 and discharged 2 weeks ago on 2021-08-15 after being treated for Acute on chronic decompensated systolic heart failure with IV diuresis (first bumex gtt and then bumex IVP while on home milrinone gtt 0.375). That admission was thought to be 2/2 intake of high sodium and water, which pt attributed to diabetes. He had presented with gradual worsening of DOE, peripheral and central edema over a course of several weeks to the point of SOA at rest. He was discharged on bumex 3mg po tid, metolazone MWF, home milrinone 0.375 mcg/kg/min, as well as metoprolol XL, aldactone, and farxiga (farxiga reportedly not started by pt).
Today he presents to ER after feeling generally unwell, SOA, and having subjective fever and cough. No objective fever on presentation to ER, however having an elevated WBC to 16K, AKI on CKD Cr 3 (baseline ~2), and hyperkalemia 6.3. Also having INR 2.73. He takes xarelto at home which is known to elevate INR. No bleed.
No CP. Troponin 0.08. Covid nasopharyngeal swab negative. CT chest not concerning for covid-19.
See ROS below for additional findings.
His dry weight is close to 238 lbs. Not accurately recorded today, says he is 60kg which is not true.

_Admitted and treated for Sepsis, also incidentally found Cirrhosis on imaging. Liver c/s and Liver Biopsy shows minimal fibrosis with no evidence of cirrhosis. Discharged home on milrinone.

Impression and Plan
Impression/Diagnosis & Management: (2/3/4) [(New + W/U (4), New (3), Worsened (2), Stable (1), Improved (1), Self-Limited (1)]
consistent with congestive hepatopathy. We do not see evidence of advanced fibrosis
50 yo M pmh of AFib (on warfarin), HFrEF (39%, 4/2017), T2DM and no previous h/o liver cirrhosis who was admitted for acute on chronic decompensated HFrEF, currently being workup for VAD. GI is consulted due to abnormal CT scan, concerning for possible cirrhosis.
#Congestive hepatopathy
- CT chest on 2021-08-31 showing nodularity to the surface of the liver, mildly enlarged spleen, cannot exclude cirrhosis
- Patient denies alcohol use or previous h/o hepatitis. Clinical exam is benign with no abdominal distention or GI symptom
- AST, ALT, Tbili on admission wnl. Hepatitis panel negative.
- Duplex U/S with cirrhotic liver, however, patent hepatic vessels. Cirrhosis is likely related to CHF, could also be component of NASH as well.
- Plan: Liver pathology is consistent with congestive hepatopathy. No evidence of advanced fibrosis. GI will sign off.
#Sepsis
- PICC removed, currently on Cefepime, culture catheter tip positive Stenotrophomonas maltophilia
- mmgt per primary team
#Acute on chronic decompensated systolic HF
- Currently on Bumex and Milrinone. Possible VAD per primary team
Thank you for consulting our service. If further question please call or page.
RESIDENT/FELLOW ATTESTATION: Dr. Marsano , the teaching attending-physician, was present during the exam and decision making component of this evaluation. The note reflects the joint assessment and management decision.

Undiagnosed new problem with uncertain prognosis. 4. Acute illness with systemic symptoms. 5. Acute complicated injury. 6. Closed treatment of fracture or dislocation without manipulation.
CRITICAL CARE STATEMENT:
ATTENDING ATTESTATION: Attending Attestation: I performed a history and physical examination of the patient and discussed the management with the Resident/Fellow. I reviewed the Resident’s/Fellow’s note and agree with the documented findings and plan of care.

Result: Name: Michael Daniel PARKERMRN: D002199327FIN: D2036600432Accession No: 01XA210000018Sex: Male DOB: 1970-12-03 Age: 50 yearsStudy Date/Time: 2021-09-06 8:00 AMStudy Description: XA Biopsy LiverAttending Physician: DO-CAR Henry DUNBAR MATOSOrdering Physician: Fellow PRANEETH S KATRAPATIReferring Physician: SELF REFERRED PHYPrimary Care Physician: Fellow PRANEETH S KATRAPATIProcedure: Transjugular liver biopsyComplications: NoneMedications: Versed 1 mg iv, Fentanyl 100 mcg iv. Moderate sedation was monitored byradiology nursing staff.Indication: Elevated liver enzymes with concern for elevated portal venous pressures.Hepatic venogram with wedged portal pressure measurements requested.Procedure: Using real-time ultrasound guidance, the right internal jugular vein waspunctured and a vascular sheath was placed. Selective catheterization of the righthepatic vein was performed, and a venogram was obtained. Subsequently, an angledcatheter was passed over the wire and wedged in the hepatic parenchyma. A small amountcontrast was injected to confirm parenchymal staining. Wedged hepatic venous pressureswithin obtained 13 mmHg. The catheter was subsequently retracted into the hepatic veinand free hepatic venous pressure was obtained measuring approximately 9 mmHg. Thecatheter was retracted into the right atrium and right atrial pressure was obtained at9 mmHg. For a gradient 4. Subsequently, a Cook core device was used to make 2 passeshowever no good sample sample was obtained. The catheters and wires were removed andhemostasis was achieved by mental compression. At this point, the decision was made toperform a percutaneous liver biopsy after successful pressure measurements. The rightupper quadrant was prepped and draped in usual sterile fashion. Sonographic evaluationof the right hepatic lobe was performed and a percutaneous liver biopsies and a16-gauge biopsy needle was then performed and adequate samples were obtained. Sampleswere submitted for pathologic evaluation in formalin. This procedure was performed under the personal supervision of Dr. Ohene Baah, who waspresent for the critical portion and immediately available for the remainder of theprocedure.Findings: Ultrasound shows an anechoic and compressible jugular vein. On the findings,thecal above.Impression: Successful percutaneous liver biopsy after transjugular pressuremeasurements and attempted transjugular liver biopsy. _
50 yo M pmh of AFib (on warfarin), HFrEF (39%, 4/2017), T2DM and no previous h/o liver cirrhosis who was admitted for acute on chronic decompensated HFrEF, currently being workup for VAD. GI is consulted due to abnormal CT scan, concerning for possible cirrhosis.
#Possible liver cirrhosis
- CT chest on 2021-08-31 showing nodularity to the surface of the liver, mildly enlarged spleen, cannot exclude cirrhosis
- Patient denies alcohol use or previous h/o hepatitis. Clinical exam is benign with no abdominal distention or GI symptom
- AST, ALT, Tbili on admission wnl. Hepatitis panel negative.
- Duplex U/S with cirrhotic liver, however, patent hepatic vessels. Cirrhosis is likely related to CHF, could also be component of NASH as well.
- Plan: Liver biopsy with IR on 2021-09-06. NPO at midnight. Holding anti-coag.
#Sepsis
- PICC removed, currently on Cefepime, culture catheter tip positive Stenotrophomonas maltophilia
- mmgt per primary team
#Acute on chronic decompensated systolic HF
- Currently on Bumex and Milrinone. Possible VAD per primary team
- Rest of mmgt per primary team
RESIDENT/FELLOW ATTESTATION: Dr.Marsano_ , the teaching attending-physician, was present during the exam and decision making component of this evaluation. The note reflects the joint assessment and management decision.
RISK (Minimal/Moderate/High):
CRITICAL CARE STATEMENT:
ATTENDING ATTESTATION: Attending Attestation: I performed a history and physical examination of the patient and discussed the management with the Resident/Fellow. I reviewed the Resident’s/Fellow’s note and agree with the documented findings and plan of care.
Attending Impression/Additional Note and Plan: Will have Portal Pressure measurement (Free HV + Wedge HV) today + Liver Bx. Will check results. Talked with IR.

Impression/Diagnosis & Management: (2/3/4) [(New + W/U (4), New (3), Worsened (2), Stable (1), Improved (1), Self-Limited (1)]
50 yo M pmh of AFib (on warfarin), HFrEF (39%, 4/2017), T2DM and no previous h/o liver cirrhosis who was admitted for acute on chronic decompensated HFrEF, currently being workup for VAD. GI is consulted due to abnormal CT scan, concerning for possible cirrhosis.
#Possible liver cirrhosis
- CT chest on 2021-08-31 showing nodularity to the surface of the liver, mildly enlarged spleen, cannot exclude cirrhosis
- Patient denies alcohol use or previous h/o hepatitis. Clinical exam is benign with no abdominal distention or GI symptom
- AST, ALT, Tbili on admission wnl. Hepatitis panel negative.
- Duplex U/S with cirrhotic liver, however, patent hepatic vessels. Cirrhosis is likely related to CHF, could also be component of NASH as well.
- Plan: Liver biopsy with IR on 2021-09-06. NPO at midnight. Holding anti-coag.
#Sepsis
- PICC removed, currently on Cefepime, culture catheter tip positive Stenotrophomonas maltophilia
- mmgt per primary team
#Acute on chronic decompensated systolic HF
- Currently on Bumex and Milrinone. Possible VAD per primary team
- Rest of mmgt per primary team
RESIDENT/FELLOW ATTESTATION: Dr. Marsano , the teaching attending-physician, was present during the exam and decision making component of this evaluation. The note reflects the joint assessment and management decision.
RISK (Minimal/Moderate/High):

ATTENDING ATTESTATION: Attending Attestation: I performed a history and physical examination of the patient and discussed the management with the Resident/Fellow. I reviewed the Resident’s/Fellow’s note and agree with the documented findings and plan of care.
Attending Impression/Additional Note and Plan: Feels OK. No abdominal pain. Talked with IR; they will do TOMORROW Transjugular Liver Bx + Pressure of Free Hepatic Vein + Wedge Hepatic Vein to assess for sinusoidal Portal HTN.

-bumex 3 mg IV tid

-ISMN (held), Hydral resumed (with paraemters)
-metop succinate 25 mg qd
-aldactone
-dapa to be resumed soon
AKI on CKD, stage III
-Cr improved again today with diuresis
-avoid nephrotoxic agents
-renal dose meds

-Will discuss need for further w/u including possible biopsy

-hydralazine 25 q6h w parameters
CAD
--stable, no CP, asa, statin, ismn (now held), metop

--s/p MI and PCI to RCA around 2014
T2DM

-nutritional insulin also increased
-home gaba resumed

-currently rate controlled
-xarelto, metop resumed
OSA

-complicating all aspects of care

Impression and Plan
Impression/Diagnosis & Management: (2/3/4) [(New + W/U (4), New (3), Worsened (2), Stable (1), Improved (1), Self-Limited (1)]
50 yo M pmh of AFib (on warfarin), HFrEF (39%, 4/2017), T2DM and no previous h/o liver cirrhosis who was admitted for acute on chronic decompensated HFrEF, currently being workup for VAD. GI is consulted due to abnormal CT scan, concerning for possible cirrhosis.
#Possible liver cirrhosis
- CT chest on 2021-08-31 showing nodularity to the surface of the liver, mildly enlarged spleen, cannot exclude cirrhosis
- Patient denies alcohol use or previous h/o hepatitis. Clinical exam is benign with no abdominal distention or GI symptom
- AST, ALT, Tbili on admission wnl. Hepatitis panel negative.
- Duplex U/S with cirrhotic liver, however, patent hepatic vessels. Cirrhosis is likely related to CHF, could also be component of NASH as well.
- Recs: Twinrix vaccine and continue supportive management.
#Sepsis
- PICC removed, currently on Cefepime, culture catheter tip positive Stenotrophomonas maltophilia
- mmgt per primary team
#Acute on chronic decompensated systolic HF
- Currently on Bumex and Milrinone. Possible VAD per primary team
- Rest of mmgt per primary team
RESIDENT/FELLOW ATTESTATION: Dr. Marsano , the teaching attending-physician, was present during the exam and decision making component of this evaluation. The note reflects the joint assessment and management decision.
RISK (Minimal/Moderate/High): Statement of RISK = HIGH: Due to Disease severity and/or required testing and/or management, the RISK of complications, morbidity and/or mortality is HIGH. Risk based in one or more of the following: 1. One or more chronic illnesses with severe exacerbation, progression, or side effects of treatment. 2. Acute or chronic illnesses or injuries that pose a threat to life or bodily function. 3. An abrupt change in neurologic status. 4. Cardiovascular imaging studies with contrast with identified risk factors. 5. Cardiac electrophysiological tests. 6. Diagnostic Endoscopies with identified risk factors. 7. Discography. 8. Elective major surgery (open, percutaneous or endoscopic) with identified risk factors. 9. Emergency major surgery (open, percutaneous or endoscopic). 10. Parenteral controlled substances. 11. Drug therapy requiring intensive monitoring for toxicity. 12. Decision not to resuscitate or to de-escalate care because of poor prognosis.
CRITICAL CARE STATEMENT:
ATTENDING ATTESTATION: Attending Attestation: I performed a history and physical examination of the patient and discussed the management with the Resident/Fellow. I reviewed the Resident’s/Fellow’s note and agree with the documented findings and plan of care.
Attending Impression/Additional Note and Plan: Has HFrEF in need of LVAD but may have cirrhosis, by CT Scan, but platelet count is preserved. Will need Liver Bx. Either 16 g Percutaneous Bx + plug, or Transjugular of Rt + Left side + pressure measurement, do decrease sampling error. Will talk with IR.

Was admitted on 2021-08-08 and discharged 2 weeks ago on 2021-08-15 after being treated for Acute on chronic decompensated systolic heart failure. This time he presents to ER after feeling generally unwell, SOA, and having subjective fever and cough. No objective fever on presentation to ER, however having an elevated WBC to 16K, AKI on CKD Cr 3 (baseline ~2), and hyperkalemia 6.3. Also having INR 2.73. He takes xarelto at home which is known to elevate INR. No bleed. No CP. Troponin 0.08. Covid nasopharyngeal swab negative. CT chest not concerning for covid-19. Patient has a right upper extremity PICC line since April for his IV medications at home for his pulmonary hypertension. The PICC line was removed and the cath tip was positive for more than 15 colonies of Stenotrophomonas maltophilia.Currently patient is on cefepime and vancomycin. His blood cultures are negative so far.

Result: INDICATION: Shortness of breath, cough, and body aches. Additional History:Diabetes, COPD, CHF, hypertension, defibrillator insertion, and coronary stents.TECHNIQUE: CT of the chest was performed without contrast. Automated mA/kV exposure control was utilized and patient examination was performedin strict accordance with principles of ALARA.RADIATION AMOUNT: 919.40 mGy-cm.COMPARISON: CT chest 2020-07-18.CORRELATION: XR chest 2021-08-08, 2021-07-04, 2020-07-18.FINDINGS:The heart is normal in size without pericardial effusion. There is calcified lymphnodes in the right paratracheal region. There are prominent mediastinal lymphnodes in the precarinal as well as aortopulmonary windows.There is no pleural effusion, pleural thickening, or pneumothorax. The airways arepatent.Lungs are clear without consolidation, interstitial disease, or suspicious nodules.There is nodularity to the surface of the liver and cirrhosis cannot be excluded. The spleen is mildly enlarged.There are no acute fractures. No suspicious bony lesions.IMPRESSION:Findings consistent with old granulomatous disease.Probable cirrhosis with splenomegaly.Otherwise unremarkable CT scan of the chest.Signed by Tim Miller, MD

This test was developed and its analytical performance
characteristics have been determined by Beverly

Administration. This assay has been validated pursuant
to the CLIA regulations and is used for clinical
purposes.

Beverly Diagnostics Nichols Institute
14225 Newbrook Drive
Chantilly, VA 20151
Patrick W Mason, M.D.

Result Comment:
This test is approximately 95% sensitive for
detecting antibodies to the Platelet Factor 4/Heparin
Complex (PF4/Heparin). Although the result of
this patient's sample is negative, a small
percentage of patients may still be positive
by the Serotonin Release Assay (SRA), possibly
due to other target antigens involved in this
reaction such as Interleukin-8 or Neutrophil-
Activating Peptide-2 (NAP-2). A clinical risk
assessment score may provide additional guidance
in deciding whether additional testing is of
value (J Thromb Haemost 2008;6:1304-12).

Patrick W Mason, M.D.

Result Comment:
This patient's alpha-1-antitrypsin phenotype is
PI*CM.
90% of normal individuals have the MM phenotype,
with normal quantitative AAT levels. Many
phenotypic patterns have been described, including
deficiency states with F, S, Z, or other alleles.
As a general estimation, compared to M allele of
100% of normal A-1-Antitrypsin protein, the S
allele produces approximately 60% and the Z allele
20%. For example, an MS phenotype would have about
80% of normal A-1-Antitrypsin protein level, a 50%
contribution from the M allele and 30% from the S
allele. A ZZ phenotype would have about 20% of
normal levels, a 10% contribution from each Z
gene. The F allele has normal A-1-Antitrypsin
levels, but the kinetics of elastase inhibition is
not as efficient as an M allele product; F alleles
should be considered functionally mildly
deficient. Other variants are identifiable by
phenotypic analysis. These include CM, DP, EM, GM,
IS, LM, M1M2, M3M3, MP, MT, XX, MY, and M1N. I, P,
T and null alleles are considered deleterious. C,
D, E, G, L, M1, M2, M3, X and Y alleles are
generally considered normal variants. The MZ-Pratt
phenotype is a normal variant; care should be
taken to avoid confusion with the deficient MZ
phenotype.
Test performed by Beverly Diagnostics Nichols Institute
33608 Ortega Hwy,
San Juan Capistrano, CA 92675
+1-0032616224
Medical Director: Irina Maramica MD,PHD,MBA
Test Reported by Beverly, Chantilly,
Beverly Diagnostics Nichols Institute,
14225 Newbrook Drive, Chantilly, VA 20151
Patrick W Mason, M.D., Ph.D., Director of Laboratories
(703) 802-6900, CLIA 49D0221801

Beverly Diagnostics Nichols Institute
14225 Newbrook Drive
Chantilly, VA 20151
Patrick W Mason, M.D.

Result Comment:
Reference Range:
<20 U: Negative
>or=20 U: Positive
Antibodies recognizing actin are the main component
of smooth muscle antibodies associated with auto-
immune liver disease. Actin antibodies are found in
approximately 75% of patients with autoimmune
hepatitis (AIH) type 1, approximately 65% of patients
with autoimmune cholangitis, approximately 30% of
patients with primary biliary cirrhosis and
approximately 2% of healthy controls. High values are
closely correlated with AIH type 1.
Lab test performed by:

Result Comment:
Reference range(s):
Negative: 0.0 - 20.0
Equivocal: 20.1 - 24.9
Positive: >=25.0
Antibodies to soluble liver antigen (SLA) appear to be
directed against the UGA-suppressor tRNA associated
protein. These antibodies are highly specific for
autoimmune hepatitis (AIH) and may, rarely, be the only
autoantibodies detected in serum from such patients.
Antibodies to SLA are most closely associated with AIH
type 1; the presence of these antibodies in patients
with cryptogenic hepatitis suggests that these patients
may have AIH type 1. Anti-SLA antibodies may be
detected in some patients with the primary biliary
cirrhosis-AIH overlap syndrome, but not in healthy
controls.
Lab test performed by:
Lab Mnemonic: AMD
Beverly Diagnostics Nichols Institute
14225 Newbrook Drive
Chantilly, VA 20151

in approximately 70% of patients with autoimmune

item.paragraph: (XA Biopsy Liver) Reason For Exam: Cirrhosis;Other (Please Specify)

paragraph.content: REPORT

Name: Michael Daniel
mrn:l639927454
fin:J8253761877
accession no:89wT913304004
Sex: Male DOB: 1970-12-03 Age: 50 years
Study Date/Time: 2021-09-06 8:00 AM
Study Description: XA Biopsy Liver
Attending Physician: DO-CAR Henry
Ordering Physician: Fellow PRANEETH S KATRAPATI
Referring Physician: SELF REFERRED PHY
Primary Care Physician: Fellow PRANEETH S KATRAPATI
Procedure: Transjugular liver biopsy
Complications: None
Medications: Versed 1 mg iv, Fentanyl 100 mcg iv. Moderate sedation was monitored by
radiology nursing staff.
Indication: Elevated liver enzymes with concern for elevated portal venous pressures.
Hepatic venogram with wedged portal pressure measurements requested.
Procedure: Using real-time ultrasound guidance, the right internal jugular vein was
punctured and a vascular sheath was placed. Selective catheterization of the right
hepatic vein was performed, and a venogram was obtained. Subsequently, an angled
catheter was passed over the wire and wedged in the hepatic parenchyma. A small amount
contrast was injected to confirm parenchymal staining. Wedged hepatic venous pressures
within obtained 13 mmHg. The catheter was subsequently retracted into the hepatic vein
and free hepatic venous pressure was obtained measuring approximately 9 mmHg. The
catheter was retracted into the right atrium and right atrial pressure was obtained at
9 mmHg. For a gradient 4. Subsequently, a Cook core device was used to make 2 passes
however no good sample sample was obtained. The catheters and wires were removed and
hemostasis was achieved by mental compression. At this point, the decision was made to
perform a percutaneous liver biopsy after successful pressure measurements. The right
upper quadrant was prepped and draped in usual sterile fashion. Sonographic evaluation
of the right hepatic lobe was performed and a percutaneous liver biopsies and a
16-gauge biopsy needle was then performed and adequate samples were obtained. Samples
were submitted for pathologic evaluation in formalin.
This procedure was performed under the personal supervision of Dr. Ohene Baah, who was
present for the critical portion and immediately available for the remainder of the
procedure.
Findings: Ultrasound shows an anechoic and compressible jugular vein. On the findings,
thecal above.
Impression: Successful percutaneous liver biopsy after transjugular pressure
measurements and attempted transjugular liver biopsy. Wedged hepatic venous pressure
was 13 mmHg, free hepatic venous pressure was 9 mmHg for a gradient of 4.

paragraph.content: Patient Education
Heart Failure

text.paragraph:
Heart Failure
Heart failure is a condition in which the heart has trouble pumping blood. This means your heart does not pump blood efficiently for your body to work well. In some cases of heart failure, fluid may back up into your lungs or you may have swelling (edema) in your lower legs. Heart failure is usually a long-term (chronic) condition. It is important for you to take good care of yourself and follow your health care provider's treatment plan.
CAUSES
Some health conditions can cause heart failure. Those health conditions include:
• High blood pressure (hypertension). Hypertension causes the heart muscle to work harder than normal. When pressure in the blood vessels is high, the heart needs to pump (contract) with more force in order to circulate blood throughout the body. High blood pressure eventually causes the heart to become stiff and weak.
• Coronary artery disease (CAD). CAD is the buildup of cholesterol and fat (plaque) in the arteries of the heart. The blockage in the arteries deprives the heart muscle of oxygen and blood. This can cause chest pain and may lead to a heart attack. High blood pressure can also contribute to CAD.
• Heart attack (myocardial infarction). A heart attack occurs when one or more arteries in the heart become blocked. The loss of oxygen damages the muscle tissue of the heart. When this happens, part of the heart muscle dies. The injured tissue does not contract as well and weakens the heart's ability to pump blood.
• Abnormal heart valves. When the heart valves do not open and close properly, it can cause heart failure. This makes the heart muscle pump harder to keep the blood flowing.
• Heart muscle disease (cardiomyopathy or myocarditis). Heart muscle disease is damage to the heart muscle from a variety of causes. These can include drug or alcohol abuse, infections, or unknown reasons. These can increase the risk of heart failure.
• Lung disease. Lung disease makes the heart work harder because the lungs do not work properly. This can cause a strain on the heart, leading it to fail.
• Diabetes. Diabetes increases the risk of heart failure. High blood sugar contributes to high fat (lipid) levels in the blood. Diabetes can also cause slow damage to tiny blood vessels that carry important nutrients to the heart muscle. When the heart does not get enough oxygen and food, it can cause the heart to become weak and stiff. This leads to a heart that does not contract efficiently.
• Other conditions can contribute to heart failure. These include abnormal heart rhythms, thyroid problems, and low blood counts (anemia).
Certain unhealthy behaviors can increase the risk of heart failure, including:
• Being overweight.
• Smoking or chewing tobacco.
• Eating foods high in fat and cholesterol.
• Abusing illicit drugs or alcohol.
• Lacking physical activity.
SYMPTOMS
Heart failure symptoms may vary and can be hard to detect. Symptoms may include:
• Shortness of breath with activity, such as climbing stairs.
• Persistent cough.
• Swelling of the feet, ankles, legs, or abdomen.
• Unexplained weight gain.
• Difficulty breathing when lying flat (orthopnea).
• Waking from sleep because of the need to sit up and get more air.
• Rapid heartbeat.
• Fatigue and loss of energy.
• Feeling light-headed, dizzy, or close to fainting.
• Loss of appetite.
• Nausea.
• Increased urination during the night (nocturia).
DIAGNOSIS
A diagnosis of heart failure is based on your history, symptoms, physical examination, and diagnostic tests. Diagnostic tests for heart failure may include:
• Echocardiography.
• Electrocardiography.
• Chest X-Cindy.
• Blood tests.
• Exercise stress test.
• Cardiac angiography.
• Radionuclide scans.
TREATMENT
Treatment is aimed at managing the symptoms of heart failure. Medicines, behavioral changes, or surgical intervention may be necessary to treat heart failure.
• Medicines to help treat heart failure may include:
○ Angiotensin-converting enzyme (ACE) inhibitors. This type of medicine blocks the effects of a blood protein called angiotensin-converting enzyme. ACE inhibitors relax (dilate) the blood vessels and help lower blood pressure.
○ Angiotensin receptor blockers (ARBs). This type of medicine blocks the actions of a blood protein called angiotensin. Angiotensin receptor blockers dilate the blood vessels and help lower blood pressure.
○ Water pills (diuretics). Diuretics cause the kidneys to remove salt and water from the blood. The extra fluid is removed through urination. This loss of extra fluid lowers the volume of blood the heart pumps.
○ Beta blockers. These prevent the heart from beating too fast and improve heart muscle strength.
○ Digitalis. This increases the force of the heartbeat.
• Healthy behavior changes include:
○ Obtaining and maintaining a healthy weight.
○ Stopping smoking or chewing tobacco.
○ Eating heart-healthy foods.
○ Limiting or avoiding alcohol.
○ Stopping illicit drug use.
○ Physical activity as directed by your health care provider.
• Surgical treatment for heart failure may include:
○ A procedure to open blocked arteries, repair damaged heart valves, or remove damaged heart muscle tissue.
○ A pacemaker to improve heart muscle function and control certain abnormal heart rhythms.
○ An internal cardioverter defibrillator to treat certain serious abnormal heart rhythms.
○ A left ventricular assist device (LVAD) to assist the pumping ability of the heart.
HOME CARE INSTRUCTIONS
• Take medicines only as directed by your health care provider. Medicines are important in reducing the workload of your heart, slowing the progression of heart failure, and improving your symptoms.
○ Do not stop taking your medicine unless directed by your health care provider.
○ Do not skip any dose of medicine.
○ Refill your prescriptions before you run out of medicine. Your medicines are needed every day.
• Engage in moderate physical activity if directed by your health care provider. Moderate physical activity can benefit some people. The elderly and people with severe heart failure should consult with a health care provider for physical activity recommendations.
• Eat heart-healthy foods. Food choices should be free of trans fat and low in saturated fat, cholesterol, and salt (sodium). Healthy choices include fresh or frozen fruits and vegetables, fish, lean meats, legumes, fat-free or low-fat dairy products, and whole grain or high fiber foods. Talk to a dietitian to learn more about heart-healthy foods.
• Limit sodium if directed by your health care provider. Sodium restriction may reduce symptoms of heart failure in some people. Talk to a dietitian to learn more about heart-healthy seasonings.
• Use healthy cooking methods. Healthy cooking methods include roasting, grilling, broiling, baking, poaching, steaming, or stir-frying. Talk to a dietitian to learn more about healthy cooking methods.
• Limit fluids if directed by your health care provider. Fluid restriction may reduce symptoms of heart failure in some people.
• Weigh yourself every day. Daily weights are important in the early recognition of excess fluid. You should weigh yourself every morning after you urinate and before you eat breakfast. Wear the same amount of clothing each time you weigh yourself. Record your daily weight. Provide your health care provider with your weight record.
• Monitor and record your blood pressure if directed by your health care provider.
• Check your pulse if directed by your health care provider.
• Lose weight if directed by your health care provider. Weight loss may reduce symptoms of heart failure in some people.
• Stop smoking or chewing tobacco. Nicotine makes your heart work harder by causing your blood vessels to constrict. Do not use nicotine gum or patches before talking to your health care provider.
• Keep all follow-up visits as directed by your health care provider. This is important.
• Limit alcohol intake to no more than 1 drink per day for nonpregnant women and 2 drinks per day for men. One drink equals 12 ounces of beer, 5 ounces of wine, or 1½ ounces of hard liquor. Drinking more than that is harmful to your heart. Tell your health care provider if you drink alcohol several times a week. Talk with your health care provider about whether alcohol is safe for you. If your heart has already been damaged by alcohol or you have severe heart failure, drinking alcohol should be stopped completely.
• Stop illicit drug use.
• Stay up-to-date with immunizations. It is especially important to prevent respiratory infections through current pneumococcal and influenza immunizations.
• Manage other health conditions such as hypertension, diabetes, thyroid disease, or abnormal heart rhythms as directed by your health care provider.
• Learn to manage stress.
• Plan rest periods when fatigued.
• Learn strategies to manage high temperatures. If the weather is extremely hot:
○ Avoid vigorous physical activity.
○ Use air conditioning or fans or seek a cooler location.
○ Avoid caffeine and alcohol.
○ Wear loose-fitting, lightweight, and light-colored clothing.
• Learn strategies to manage cold temperatures. If the weather is extremely cold:
○ Avoid vigorous physical activity.
○ Layer clothes.
○ Wear mittens or gloves, a hat, and a scarf when going outside.
○ Avoid alcohol.
• Obtain ongoing education and support as needed.
• Participate in or seek rehabilitation as needed to maintain or improve independence and quality of life.
SEEK MEDICAL CARE IF:
• Your weight increases by 03 lb/1.4 kg in 1 day or 05 lb/2.3 kg in a week.
• You have increasing shortness of breath that is unusual for you.
• You are unable to participate in your usual physical activities.
• You tire easily.
• You cough more than normal, especially with physical activity.
• You have any or more swelling in areas such as your hands, feet, ankles, or abdomen.
• You are unable to sleep because it is hard to breathe.
• You feel like your heart is beating fast (palpitations).
• You become dizzy or light-headed upon standing up.
SEEK IMMEDIATE MEDICAL CARE IF:
• You have difficulty breathing.
• There is a change in mental status such as decreased alertness or difficulty with concentration.
• You have a pain or discomfort in your chest.
• You have an episode of fainting (syncope).
MAKE SURE YOU:
• Understand these instructions.
• Will watch your condition.
• Will get help right away if you are not doing well or get worse.
Document Released: 2007-08-18 Document Revised: 2016-01-04 Document Reviewed: 2014-09-17
